evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as evidenced by the historical pair engine preliminary data at time zero.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical pair engine preliminary data and crew reports.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew interactions, and coordination patterns noted in the historical pair engine preliminary data.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against alternative explanations, supported by consistent evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim data on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in pushback operations, including timing, crew actions, and environmental conditions specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t0_prelim phase.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as evidenced by the historical pair engine preliminary data at time zero.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP despite communication attempts indicates a coordination failure.
The headset operator and tug crew communication reflects crew coordination relevant to the claim.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors, or if the pushback deviation was due to procedural deviation unrelated to communication.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, but the pushback continued beyond the stop point causing a collision, supporting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown (R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN).
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the pushback error was due to communication breakdown or procedural deviation

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew interactions, and coordination patterns noted in the historical pair engine preliminary data.

assumptions: The described interactions and pushback events reflect communication/coordination breakdown features relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.
The discriminator correctly distinguishes coordination failure from procedural deviation based on stop-point and continuation behavior.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without errors or if procedural deviations better explained the incident.
If timing or interaction patterns did not align with those observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 directly describe crew communication and coordination patterns during pushback, showing breakdowns consistent with the claim and discriminating from procedural deviation per discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited detail on exact timing and internal crew cognitive states; some ambiguity in distinguishing coordination failure from procedural deviation.
